Description: Rim and body sherd of Chian black-figured Sphinx and Lion Style pottery plate; yellowish cream slip; on rim, maeander band (showing final squeezing in of one element) between black bands; below, billet pattern between narrow brown bands; inside, incised decoration consisting of pendant rosette with added red at its centre; undetermined motif below, possibly part of lion's mane; exterior: four bands, fired brown.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Royal Museum of Art and History, Brussels. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Lemos places this sherd in Group A of the Sphinx and Lion Style. The decoration on the vases from this group is the most elaborate. The rosette has a standard cogwheel shape, the figures are carefully drawn and details are expertly incised.
Bibliographic references: CVA Brussels III / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Belgique (p. 2, pl. 2, no. 4)
Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 147, p. 319, no. 1414, pl. 181)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.2146) (phase 2)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Musées Royaux d’Art et d’Histoire, Brussels
Acquisition notes: Purchased in Cairo by M. Jean de Mot
